metadata.purpose: Rules for identifying billing patterns that may warrant patient inquiry
metadata.important: These rules identify POTENTIAL areas for questions, NOT definitive errors
metadata.disclaimer: Always recommend patients verify concerns with their provider or insurance

language: This could be worth asking about...
There may be valid reasons for this, but you could clarify...

DUPLICATE_CHARGE.name: Potential Duplicate Charge
DUPLICATE_CHARGE.description: Same code appears multiple times on the same date of service

detection.condition: Same CPT/HCPCS code billed 2+ times on same date
exceptions: Physical therapy codes (97XXX) - often billed multiple times per session in 15-min units
Multiple injection sites (e.g., multiple joint injections)

DUPLICATE_CHARGE.userMessage: We noticed the code {code} ({description}) appears {count} times on {date}. This could be intentional if the service was performed multiple times, or it might be worth confirming with the billing department.
DUPLICATE_CHARGE.suggestedQuestion: I see {code} billed {count} times on {date}. Can you help me understand if this was performed multiple times or if this might be a duplicate entry?
commonValidReasons: Service was actually performed multiple times

UNBUNDLING_POSSIBLE.name: Potentially Unbundled Services
UNBUNDLING_POSSIBLE.description: Services billed separately that are sometimes included together

pairs.note: Blood draw + CBC - some facilities include venipuncture in lab panel pricing
Blood draw + CMP - venipuncture sometimes bundled
Office visit + injection administration - sometimes included in visit, sometimes separate
Office visit + EKG - some facilities include EKG in visit for cardiac complaints
ER visit + chest X-ray - generally appropriate to bill separately

exceptions: Clear clinical indication for separate services

UNBUNDLING_POSSIBLE.userMessage: We noticed {code1} and {code2} were both billed. These services are sometimes bundled together at some facilities. There may be good reasons for separate billing, but you could ask if combined pricing was available.
UNBUNDLING_POSSIBLE.suggestedQuestion: I see separate charges for {description1} and {description2}. Are these typically billed together at your facility, or is there a bundled price available?
commonValidReasons: Facility billing policy bills these separately

HIGH_QUANTITY.name: High Unit Quantity
HIGH_QUANTITY.description: Number of units seems high for the service type

97110.note: PT exercises - more than 4 units (60 min) in one session is unusual

97140.note: Manual therapy - more than 45 min unusual

J7030.note: Saline bags - 3+ liters in outpatient unusual

exceptions: Severe dehydration requiring multiple IV bags

HIGH_QUANTITY.userMessage: The quantity of {quantity} units for {code} ({description}) is higher than typical. This could be appropriate for your situation, but you might ask for documentation explaining the extended service.
HIGH_QUANTITY.suggestedQuestion: I see {quantity} units of {description}. Can you help me understand what required the extended treatment time?

DATE_MISMATCH.name: Date Inconsistency
DATE_MISMATCH.description: Service date doesn't match expected patterns

patterns: Service date is a Sunday for routine outpatient
Service date is before patient's stated appointment date
Lab results dated before specimen collection
exceptions: Urgent care and ER operate on weekends
Some lab tests processed on different day than collection

DATE_MISMATCH.userMessage: The service date of {date} seems unusual for this type of service. This could be a documentation issue worth verifying.
DATE_MISMATCH.suggestedQuestion: Can you confirm the date of service? I want to make sure the {date} date is correct for when I received care.
commonValidReasons: Lab processing date vs collection date

PRICE_OUTLIER_HIGH.name: Higher Than Typical Price
PRICE_OUTLIER_HIGH.description: Charge is significantly above typical price ranges

detection.threshold: Charged amount exceeds typical high range by 50% or more
exceptions: Hospital-based facility fees are typically higher than freestanding
After-hours or emergency services may have premiums
Geographic variation (prices vary significantly by region)

PRICE_OUTLIER_HIGH.userMessage: The charge of ${amount} for {code} ({description}) is on the higher end of typical ranges (${typicalLow}-${typicalHigh}). There may be valid reasons such as facility type, complexity, or location. You might ask for an itemized breakdown.
PRICE_OUTLIER_HIGH.suggestedQuestion: Can you provide an itemized breakdown of the ${amount} charge for {description}? I'd like to understand what's included.

FACILITY_FEE_UNEXPECTED.name: Separate Facility Fee
FACILITY_FEE_UNEXPECTED.description: Facility fee charged in addition to professional fee

indicators: G0463 (hospital clinic visit) paired with 99XXX codes
Separate facility charge from doctor charge
Two bills for same date - one from facility, one from provider

FACILITY_FEE_UNEXPECTED.userMessage: You were charged a facility fee (${facilityAmount}) in addition to the professional/doctor fee. This is common at hospital-owned clinics but may not occur at independent practices. It's legitimate but worth understanding.
FACILITY_FEE_UNEXPECTED.suggestedQuestion: I see a facility fee separate from the doctor's fee. Is this clinic hospital-owned? Are there independent practices nearby that might have different pricing?
commonValidReasons: Required for Medicare billing in hospital settings
FACILITY_FEE_UNEXPECTED.education: Many hospitals have purchased physician practices. These 'hospital-owned' clinics can charge both a doctor fee AND a facility fee, unlike independent practices. The care may be identical, but the billing is different.

MODIFIER_MISSING_OR_UNUSUAL.name: Modifier Question
MODIFIER_MISSING_OR_UNUSUAL.description: Modifier usage that might warrant inquiry

patterns: -25 modifier (significant separate E&M) used with minor procedure - commonly appropriate but sometimes questioned
-59 modifier (distinct procedure) - indicates services billed separately that are sometimes bundled
-76 modifier (repeat procedure same physician) - should correspond to truly repeated service

MODIFIER_MISSING_OR_UNUSUAL.userMessage: This charge includes modifier {modifier}, which indicates {modifierMeaning}. This is often appropriate but adds to the total cost.

education.-25: Modifier -25 means the office visit was significant and separate from a procedure performed the same day. This allows billing for both the visit and procedure. It's commonly used and often appropriate when the doctor spent meaningful time on evaluation beyond the procedure itself.
education.-59: Modifier -59 indicates a distinct procedural service that the billing system might otherwise bundle together. It justifies separate payment for services that are normally included.
education.-76: Modifier -76 means the same procedure was repeated by the same physician. You should see corresponding duplicate services.

SERVICE_NOT_MATCHING_DIAGNOSIS.name: Service-Diagnosis Relationship
SERVICE_NOT_MATCHING_DIAGNOSIS.description: Service may not clearly relate to listed diagnosis

examples: Knee X-ray with ankle sprain diagnosis
Cardiac testing with respiratory diagnosis only
Lab panels that don't match complaint
exceptions: Screening tests may have different diagnosis codes
Limited context available - clinical judgment required

SERVICE_NOT_MATCHING_DIAGNOSIS.userMessage: We noticed {procedure} was performed with a diagnosis of {diagnosis}. There may be clinical reasons for this we can't see, but you could ask your provider how this test related to your condition.
SERVICE_NOT_MATCHING_DIAGNOSIS.suggestedQuestion: Can you help me understand why {procedure} was ordered for my {diagnosis}? I want to make sure I understand my care.
SERVICE_NOT_MATCHING_DIAGNOSIS.important: We cannot determine medical necessity - only the treating provider can. This is for understanding, not challenging appropriateness.

SAME_SERVICE_MULTIPLE_PROVIDERS.name: Same Service, Different Providers
SAME_SERVICE_MULTIPLE_PROVIDERS.description: Similar services billed by different providers same day

detection.pattern: Same or very similar CPT code billed by different NPIs on same date
commonScenarios: Hospital + physician billing for same ER visit (expected)
Two physicians billing for same service (investigate)

SAME_SERVICE_MULTIPLE_PROVIDERS.userMessage: We see similar charges from different providers on {date}. This is sometimes expected (like hospital and doctor fees for ER visits), but you might verify these are for different services.
SAME_SERVICE_MULTIPLE_PROVIDERS.suggestedQuestion: I received bills from {provider1} and {provider2} for similar services on {date}. Can you explain what each charge covers?
commonValidReasons: Hospital facility fee + physician professional fee (ER, surgery)

PREVENTIVE_VS_DIAGNOSTIC.name: Preventive vs Diagnostic Coding
PREVENTIVE_VS_DIAGNOSTIC.description: Service that might have been coded as diagnostic instead of preventive

detection.pattern: Services that could be preventive billed with diagnostic codes
examples: Annual physical coded as 99214 instead of 99395
Routine lab work with symptomatic diagnosis
detection.importance: Preventive services often have better insurance coverage (often 100% covered), while diagnostic may be subject to deductible

PREVENTIVE_VS_DIAGNOSTIC.userMessage: This {service} was billed as diagnostic rather than preventive/screening. If this was a routine preventive service, you might ask if the coding is correct, as preventive care may have different (often better) coverage.
PREVENTIVE_VS_DIAGNOSTIC.suggestedQuestion: My insurance covers preventive care at 100%, but this {service} was coded as diagnostic. Was there a specific reason it wasn't considered preventive/routine?
commonValidReasons: Symptoms reported during visit (turns preventive into diagnostic)
Doctor found something that required additional evaluation
Already had same screening within coverage period
PREVENTIVE_VS_DIAGNOSTIC.education: If you mention ANY symptoms during a preventive visit, the visit may be coded as diagnostic. This can change your coverage. Some patients schedule separate appointments for wellness vs. symptom discussions.

ER_LEVEL_HIGH.name: High ER Visit Level
ER_LEVEL_HIGH.description: Emergency department visit coded at high level

detection.pattern: 99284 or 99285 codes for seemingly minor complaints
detection.context: ER level is determined by complexity of evaluation, resources used, and risk - not just the final diagnosis

ER_LEVEL_HIGH.userMessage: Your ER visit was coded at level {level} (99284/99285), which is a higher-complexity level. ER coding is based on the resources and evaluation required during your visit, not just the final diagnosis. If you had testing done or required significant evaluation, this may be appropriate.
ER_LEVEL_HIGH.suggestedQuestion: My ER visit was coded as high complexity. Can you help me understand what criteria determined this level?
commonValidReasons: Initial presentation was concerning even if diagnosis was minor
Time spent on evaluation was significant
ER_LEVEL_HIGH.education: ER visits are coded based on what was required to evaluate you, not what turned out to be wrong. Chest pain that turns out to be heartburn still requires cardiac workup - and that workup drives the level.

NON_COVERED_SERVICE.name: Non-Covered Service
NON_COVERED_SERVICE.description: Service marked as not covered by insurance

detection.pattern: A9270 code or denial reason indicating non-covered service

NON_COVERED_SERVICE.userMessage: One or more services are marked as not covered by your insurance. You may want to understand why - sometimes this is correct (cosmetic, experimental) and sometimes it can be appealed.
NON_COVERED_SERVICE.suggestedQuestion: Can you tell me why {service} was not covered? Is there an appeal process or alternative coding that might be covered?
commonValidReasons: Service is explicitly excluded from plan
actions: Review your insurance benefits to confirm exclusion
Ask if service can be coded differently (if appropriate)
Request pre-authorization for future similar services
Appeal if you believe it should be covered

EMERGENCY_VISIT_BUNDLE.userMessage: ER visits typically generate multiple bills: the hospital facility fee, the emergency physician fee, and possibly separate bills from radiologists, labs, or specialists who were consulted. This is normal for ER visits.

ANNUAL_PHYSICAL_BUNDLE.note: If symptomatic diagnosis code present, visit may be split into preventive + diagnostic
ANNUAL_PHYSICAL_BUNDLE.userMessage: Annual physicals typically include the exam, blood draw, and basic lab panel. If additional testing was done or symptoms were discussed, you may see extra charges.

OFFICE_VISIT_WITH_PROCEDURE.description: Office visit plus minor procedure same day
OFFICE_VISIT_WITH_PROCEDURE.userMessage: When a procedure is done during an office visit, you may see charges for both the visit (with modifier -25) and the procedure. This is appropriate when the doctor spent significant time on evaluation beyond just the procedure.

general.itemizedBill: Can I get an itemized bill showing each charge separately?
general.priceList: Do you have a price list or chargemaster I can review?
general.financialAssistance: Do you offer financial assistance or payment plans?
general.cashPrice: What would the cash/self-pay price be for these services?
general.coding: Can you explain what code {code} represents and why it was used?

insurance.denial: My insurance denied this claim. Can you help me understand why and whether it can be appealed?
insurance.preAuth: Was pre-authorization obtained for {service}? Can I see documentation?
insurance.inNetwork: Can you confirm whether the provider was in-network with my insurance?
insurance.preventive: Was this service coded as preventive or diagnostic? Can you explain why?

specific.facility_fee: I see both a facility fee and a doctor fee. Can you explain what each covers?
specific.multiple_bills: I received multiple bills for my {date} visit. Can you help me understand each one?
specific.level_of_service: My visit was coded as level {level}. Can you explain what determines this?

patientRights.itemizedBill: You have the right to request an itemized bill showing each service and charge
patientRights.priceEstimate: Under the No Surprises Act, you can request a Good Faith Estimate for scheduled services
patientRights.appeal: You have the right to appeal insurance denials through your insurance company
patientRights.financialAssistance: Non-profit hospitals are required to have financial assistance policies
patientRights.pricingTransparency: Hospitals are required to post pricing information publicly
